description:
levirate +‎ -ical.
From Latin levir (“a husband's brother, brother-in-law”), akin to Ancient Greek δᾱήρ (dāḗr). Compare French lévirat (“leviration”).

adjectives.description: leviratical (comparative more leviratical, superlative most leviratical)

entries.meaning: Of, relating to, or in accordance with levirate marriage.
examples: The first-born son of a leviratical marriage was reckoned and registered as the son of the deceased brother.
